A new metal−organic complex with coordination unsaturated Co(II) as high-efficiency heterogeneous catalyst for selective oxidation of alkylbenzenes Yu-Yao Li 1 Xiao-Hui Li 1 Na Xu Zhi-Xuan An Yang Chu Xiu-Li Wang ⁎ College of Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Bohai University, Professional Technology Innovation Center of Liaoning Province for Conversion Materials of Solar Cell, Jinzhou 121013, PR China College of Chemistry and Materials Engineering Bohai University Professional Technology Innovation Center of Liaoning Province for Conversion Materials of Solar Cell Jinzhou 121013 PR China College of Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Bohai University, Professional Technology Innovation Center of Liaoning Province for Conversion Materials of Solar Cell, Jinzhou 121013, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Yu-Yao Li and Xiao-Hui Li contributed equally to this work. Converting C–H bonds into valuable compounds is a challenging goal in synthetic chemistry, yet it is both economically and environmentally beneficial. Developing high-efficiency catalysts for the oxidation of saturated C–H bonds is of great significance. Herein, a new cobalt-containing metal-organic complex, [Co2(L)0.5(MTC)(µ3-OH)(H2O)2]·2H2O (1, L = (E)-4,4′-(ethene-1,2-diyl)bis(N-(pyridin-3-yl)benzamide), H3MTC = benzene-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid), was successfully prepared with Co(NO3)2, ligand L and H3MTC through one-step hydrothermal synthesis. Complex 1 was found to be a highly effective heterogeneous catalyst for accelerating the oxidation reaction of alkylbenzenes to ketone products. The conversion of diphenylmethane to benzophenone over complex 1 was 95.6%, which was comparable to the highest values of reported transition metal-based catalysts. A possible catalytic reaction mechanism was proposed. Graphical abstract A cobalt metal-organic complex as stable and high-efficiency heterogeneous catalyst for selective oxidation of alkylbenzenes. Image, graphical abstract Keywords C-H bond oxidation Cobalt metal-organic complex Heterogeneous catalysis Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. Introduction Aromatic ketones and aldehydes play a crucial role in the production of many high-valued chemicals, including pharmaceuticals, dyes, pesticides, and perfumes [1–3], while direct oxidation of benzyl CH bonds to C = O bonds is an economic and green strategy in chemical industry production. However, achieving the activation of CH bonds under mild conditions is still a challenging goal due to thermodynamic strength and kinetic inertia of saturated CH bonds [4–6]. Traditionally, a variety of stoichiometric oxidants such as CrO3 and KMnO4 have been commonly used in this process. However, they have been gradually eliminated owing to the formation of metal pollution [7–9]. In addition, a number of Pd- or Ru-containing complexes have been found to be highly effective catalysts for selectively oxidizing CH bonds [10–12]. However, they are expensive, which are not in line with economic and environmental principles [13,14]. Transition metal compounds, especially cobalt-containing compounds, exhibit excellent catalytic effects for the oxidation of CH bonds [15–17]. For example, cobalt acetate has been used to catalyze the selective oxidation of methylarenes to benzaldehydes [15], cyclohexanone to adipic acid [16], as well as the aerobic oxidation of p-xylene [17]. However, cobalt acetate as a homogeneous catalyst is difficult to be separated from the reaction system. Therefore, the development of high-efficiency, green, reusable heterogeneous Co-based catalysts is extremely meaningful. Metal-organic complexes (MOCs) are a class of crystalline materials composed of metal ions (or metal clusters) and multiple connecting ligands, which have been widely used in magnetic [18], clinical medical chemistry [19], catalysis [20] and sensing [21,22], owing to their structural diversity and functional adaptability. Especially in the field of catalysis, MOCs have become one of the popular heterogeneous catalysts because of their highly catalytic activity in various oxidation processes, such as water oxidation [23], sulfide oxidation [24] and alcohol oxidation [25]. In these oxidation processes, transition metal centers in MOCs are commonly regarded as catalytic active sites to accelerate the reaction progress. Considering the excellent catalytic activity of Co(II), Co-MOCs have the potential to become a class of potential candidates to achieve the high-efficiency oxidation of alkylbenzenes and overcome the recovery difficulty of traditional Co-catalysts. However, reports on the catalysis oxidation of benzyl CH bonds with Co-MOCs are still very limited as we know. Polycarboxylic acid and nitrogen-rich ligands are outstanding candidates for building novel MOCs, resulting from their abundant coordination sites and various coordination modes. In this study, we selected a bis-pyridyl-bis-amide (E)-4,4′-(ethene-1,2-diyl)bis(N-(pyridin-3-yl)benzamide) (L, Figure S1) as the primary ligand and benzene-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid (H3MTC, Figure S2) as the co-ligand to construct the Co-MOC catalyst. A new MOC with the molecular formula of [Co2(L)0.5(MTC)(µ3-OH)(H2O)2]·2H2O (1) was successfully synthesized by hydrothermal method. Complex 1 was activated by heating to remove coordination water molecules on Co(II) atoms, obtaining complex 1a with coordination unsaturated Co(II) sites. Complex 1a showed excellent reactivity in selectively oxidizing CH bonds to C = O bonds. Experimental section Synthesis of [Co2(L)0.5(MTC)(µ3-OH)(H2O)2]·2H2O The ligand L was prepared according to the synthesis method in the literature [26]. Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.060 g, 0.2 mmol), L (0.042 g, 0.1 mmol) and H3MTC (0.032 g, 0.15 mmol) were added successively in Teflon-lined autoclave. Then an aqueous solution (12 mL) containing NaOH (0.25 mmol) was added and stirred for 30 min. The mixture was put into the oven and heated to 160 °C for 96 h. After cooling down to the room temperature, the pink flake product was obtained. Based on the amount of raw materials and the formula of complex 1, the theoretical yield of complex 1 was calculated to be 62 mg, the actual yield of complex 1 was 21 mg, and the yield was 33% (based on Co). Oxidation procedures of alkylbenzene Firstly, the catalyst was heated in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 10 h to remove the coordination and free water molecules in the structure. Whereafter, the substrate (1 mmol), activated catalyst (0.03 mmol), dichloromethane and acetonitrile mixed solvent (1 mL, with the volume ratio of dichloromethane: acetonitrile = 1:9) and TBHP (4 mmol) were added into the glass sealed tube. The above suspension was then heated in a parallel reactor while being stirred under the rated temperature. Utilizing naphthalene as the internal standard, the GC was used to assess the conversion and selectivity. After the reaction, the catalyst was collected by centrifugation and cleaned using absolute ethanol and then dried in an oven at 75 °C. For the comparative experiment on the catalytic performance of different components of complex 1, for two components or three different components, the amount of each component of the substance ratio is half or one-third of the total amount of catalyst. Results and discussion Complex 1 was prepared through the self-assembly of Co(NO3)2, L ligand and H3MTC. The crystal structure was confirmed using single crystal X-ray diffraction, revealing that it belongs to the P-l space group of the triclinic system. The crystal structure information of 1 was showed in Table S1 and S2. Its molecular composition includes two Co(II) ions (Co1 and Co2), one TMC anion, half of L ligand, one µ3-OH group, two coordinated water molecules, and two free water molecules. Fig. 1 a illustrates that both Co1 and Co2 have hexacoordinated octahedral configurations. Co1 is coordinated with three carboxyl O atoms from three MTC anions, one µ3-OH oxygen atom, one O atom from a coordination water molecule and one pyridine N atom from a L ligand. The six coordination atoms of Co2 are O atoms, three of which are from carboxyl groups of MTC anion, one is from coordination water molecule, and two are from µ3-OH. Four Co(II) atoms link six carboxyl groups and two µ3-OH to form a quad-nucleated cluster (Figure S3). These Co(II) clusters were further linked by MTC ligands to give a 2D bilayer structure (Fig. 1b). A 3D network structure is created by further connecting the adjacent 2D layers with L ligands. (Fig. 1c). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared spectra (IR) and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were used to further characterize complex 1. As shown in IR spectrum of 1 (Figure S4), the peaks at 1609 and 1488 cm−1 can be ascribed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxyl groups of H3MTC [27]. The peaks at 1667 cm−1 suggest the stretching vibration of amide from L ligand [28]. The peaks located at 1397, 1074 cm−1 suggest the ν(C–N) of the pyridyl rings from L ligand [29]. As can be seen in Fig. 2 a, the main peaks of as-prepared 1 agree with those of the simulated ones, demonstrating the well phase purity of collected 1 crystals. In addition, the stability of complex 1 in different acid-base environments were studied, exhibiting an endurance in the pH range of 4–8. Subsequently, the PXRD patterns of complex 1 after immersing in different solvents (water, methylene chloride, ethanol, acetonitrile) were recorded (Fig. 2b). The hardly changed peak positions indicated the excellent stability of 1 in these frequently-used solvents in organic reactions. Further research was done on the thermal stability of complex 1. TG curves revealed that complex 1 had a two-step weight loss procedure between 30 and 800 °C (Figure S5). The first weight loss of 8.80% between 30 and 340 °C may be due to the loss of crystalline water. The second weight loss of 62.2% between 340 and 620 °C may be attributed to the dissociation of the ligands and the decomposition of the framework. In conclusion, complex 1 shows outstanding stability, which is very important for the further utilization of 1 in catalytic reactions. The selective oxidation of alkylbenzenes to ketones has generated a great deal of scientific interest because aromatic ketones are widely used in both pesticide and medical manufacture [2,3]. Therefore, the selective oxidation of diphenylmethane was chosen as the model reaction, and the catalytic efficiency of complex 1 was assessed using tert‑butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as an oxidant. In order to utilize the full reactivity of complex 1, complex 1 was activated by heating to remove the coordination water molecules, obtaining complex 1a with coordination unsaturated Co(II) sites. The influence of different conditions solvent, reaction temperature, catalyst and oxidant dosage was studied with 1a as catalyst (Table 1 ). Firstly, by screening the solvents, it was clearly observed that the conversion rate of diphenylmethane performed in dichloromethane (55.4%) was much higher than that of the other solvents (43.1% for CH3CN, 24.6% for CH3OH, 12.1% for C2H5OH and 22.1% for CH3COCH3), while all selectivity of benzophenone was greater than 99% (Table 1, entries 1–5). However, the catalyst stuck to the glass tube wall in the weakly polar dichloromethane solution due to the polarity of the catalyst. Thus, a strong polar solvent acetonitrile with slightly lower activity than dichloromethane was introduced into the system to disperse the catalyst, thus resulting in higher conversion of diphenylmethane (65.5%, Table 1, entry 6). Furthermore, the influence of the ratio of dichloromethane to acetonitrile on the catalytic effect was explored (Table 1, entries 6–11). The conversion rate of diphenylmethane dramatically increased (from 65.5% to 80.6%) with the increase in acetonitrile volume. When the volume ratio of dichloromethane to acetonitrile was 1:9, the catalytic effect was the best, exhibiting 80.6% conversion rate of diphenylmethane and >99% selectivity. Subsequently, the influence of reaction temperature was explored. The conversion rate improved from 80.6% to 84.2% when the reaction temperature rose from 75 °C to 90 °C. (Table 1, entries 11–13). The conversion rate remained relatively constant (84.2%, Table 1, entry 14) when the temperature increased to 100 °C, which may be originated from the more decomposition of TBHP at a higher temperature [30]. So, it could be concluded that the optimal reaction temperature was 90 °C. The effects of different catalyst dosages (0.01–0.05 mmol) during oxidation were studied. The conversion rate showed an upward trend (84.2% to 86.1%) as the amount of catalyst rose from 0.01 mmol to 0.03 mmol (Table 1, entries 13, 15–16). While the amount of catalyst continued to increase, the conversion rate decreased (86.1% to 81.6%), which may be due to the aggregation of catalysts that hindered the reaction (Table 1, entries 17–18) [31]. Therefore, the ultimate catalyst dosage was set at 0.03 mmol. It is well knowledge that oxidants are essential to the process of oxidation, and their dosage has a significant impact on the conversion and selectivity. As a result, the dosage of TBHP was studied, and 4 mmol TBHP was considered as the best choice (95.6%, Table 1, entries 18–22). Therefore, the ideal conditions for subsequent catalytic evaluation were determined: substrate 1 mmol, catalyst 0.03 mmol, solvent 1 mL (CH2Cl2/CH3CN = 1:9, V:V), TBHP 4 mmol, temperature 90 °C. In order to further detect the oxidation process of diphenylmethane catalyzed by complex 1a, the kinetic behavior of the catalytic system was explored (Figure S6). It was found that the conversion rate gradually increased within 15 h of the beginning of the reaction. And the conversion rate did not increase significantly between 15 h and 24 h, so the optimal reaction time was set as 15 h. Additionally, curves of conversion rate and ln(Ct/C0) with reaction time were shown in Fig. 3 a, where C0 and Ct represented substrate concentration in the reaction system at the initial and t times, respectively. The catalytic reaction is a pseudo-first-order kinetic process, according to the results of linear fitting (R2=0.992), and the reaction rate constant k is 0.171 h − 1. The relationship between diphenylmethane consumption and reaction time at different temperatures were also studied. As shown in Fig. 3b, k values of complex 1a were calculated to be 0.089, 0.104 and 0.171 h − 1 at 70, 80 and 90 °C, with half-lives of 7.76, 6.60 and 4.02 h, respectively. The activation energy (Ea) of catalytic oxidation reaction of diphenylmethane by complex 1a was calculated as 73.2 kJ·mol−1 according to the Arrhenius equation (Table S3). Different components of complex 1a were used as catalysts to determine the active center of the catalytic reaction. The blank experiment showed that only 31.4% diphenylmethane was converted to benzophenone in the condition without any catalyst (Table S4, entry 1). In addition, the raw components of complex 1a were used as catalysts (Table S4, entries 2 − 4). It was shown that Co(NO3)2 (88.0%) exhibited higher activity than L (32.6%) and H3MTC (40.3%), suggesting that Co(II) atoms in complex 1a acted as effective catalytic sites to catalyze this oxidation difference in catalytic conversion of diphenylmethane (Table S4, entries 5–6), further indicating the mainly catalytic effect of Co(II). Compared with the reactivity of activated complex 1a (95.6%), the conversion rate of diphenylmethane decreased obviously (83.6%) when unactivated complex 1 was used as catalyst (Table S4, entries 7–8). The above results suggested that coordination unsaturated Co(II) atoms in complex 1a after removing coordination water by heating acted as the catalytic active centers to promote the oxidation reaction of diphenylmethane. Moreover, complex 1a was comparable to the highest values of reported transition metal-based catalysts in the literature (Table 2 ) [32–40]. Among them, complex 1 has a higher or similar catalytic activity than transition metal complexes, while it doesn't need other supporters and the introduction of high active polyoxometalate units (Table 2, entries 2–8) [32–38]. Additionally, Pd-based polyoxometalate and supported cobalt nanoparticle can achieve the oxidation of diphenylmethane under O2, but significantly reduced conversion, longer reaction time and higher temperature are observed (Table 2, entries 9–10) [39,40]. Encouraged by the great results described above for diphenylmethane oxidation using TBHP as an oxidant, the range of substrates was further investigated (Table 3 ). Overall, the variable CH bond reactivity was primarily responsible for the variance in catalytic performance for various alkylbenzenes to ketone products. Under the same reaction conditions, the conversion rate of ethylbenzene was 71.6% and the selectivity was 98.5% (Table 3, entry 1). Compared with ethylbenzene, the substrate substituted by the electron-withdrawing group −NO2 showed lower conversion (60.4%) and selectivity (97.3%) (Table 3, entry 2). However, the substrate substituted by the electron-donating group −CH3 showed satisfactory conversion (83.4%) and selectivity (>99%) (Table 3, entry 3). In addition, alkylbenzenes with steric hindrance or significant volume, such as 2- benzylpyridine, tetrahydronaphthalene and fluorene, can also be converted to their corresponding ketone products with conversion rates of 83.8% to 99.0% (Table 3, entries 4–6). These favourable results indicated that activated complex 1a with coordination unsaturated Co(II) sites was suitable for selective oxidation of various alkyl benzenes. Reusability and recycling are important index to assess the performance of a heterogeneous catalyst. The heterogeneity was confirmed by thermal filtration experiments (Fig. 4 a). After 1 h of the reaction, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation. And the supernatant continued the reaction under the same condition, the conversion rate of which did not increase significantly (38.9% to 43.7%). After 15 h, the catalyst was readded to the reaction system, and the conversion rate increased from 43.7% to 95.6%, which demonstrated the catalysis and heterogeneous nature of complex 1a. After each catalytic run, complex 1a could be easily collected by centrifugation, cleaned with ethanol, and dried in an oven. Complex 1a was retrieved and utilized in later runs (Fig. 4b). Complex 1a can be recycled for 5 times without significant loss of activity (95.6% to 91.7%). After five cycles, the catalyst was collected and tested by PXRD, which indicated that the skeleton of complex 1a remained stable (Fig. 4c). Moreover, an interesting color change of the catalyst from pink to blue after heating activation was observed (illustration in Fig. 4c). We suspected that it was caused by the removal of coordination water on the metal Co, which was a typical phenomenon of whether there was coordination water on the Co ion. Subsequently, the catalyst after reaction was immersed in deionized water to verify this conjecture. As expected, the color of the catalyst returned to pink. The structure of the catalyst after soaking in water was proven to be consistent as characterized by PXRD patterns (Fig. 4c) and IR spectra (Figure S7). According to XPS spectra (Fig. 4e, f), both oxidation states of Co atoms in complex 1a before and after the catalytic process were +2. This further demonstrated the stability and cyclability of complex 1a in the oxidation process of diphenylmethane. The oxidation of the CH bond is found to include the production of carbon and oxygen radicals, according to earlier studies [37]. Therefore, in the diphenylmethane oxidation reaction system, butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) and 2,2,6,6- tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxy (TEMPO) were utilized as oxygen and carbon radical scavenger to prove the mechanism, respectively. As shown in Fig. 4d, conversion rates decreased significantly after the addition of BHT and TEMPO (25.4% and 17.6%), demonstrating the involvement of a free radical process. Considering the experimental results above and literatures [41,42], a possible reaction mechanization was presented in Fig. 5 . Firstly, the coordination water molecules of complex 1 are removed to form coordination unsaturated Co(II) sites. The activated Co(II) catalyst reacts with TBHP to create intermediate A, which further generates t-BuO• radical and Co(III) catalyst (intermediate B). Whereafter, diphenylmethane can react with t-BuO• radicals and Co(III) catalyst (intermediate B) to produce benzophenone product, respectively. Conclusions In conclusion, a new Co-MOC was successfully prepared by one-step hydrothermal synthesis method. With TBHP as oxidant and dichloromethane and acetonitrile as mixed solvent, diphenylmethane was selectively oxidized by complex 1a with remarkable catalytic activity (conversion of 95.6% and selectivity of >99%). It was proved that coordination unsaturated Co in complex 1a was used as the catalytic active center to promote the reaction. Complex 1a was able to stably repeat the oxidation reaction for five times without a noticeable loss of reactivity. Complex 1a was comparable to the highest values of reported transition metal-based catalysts. At the same time, it has heterogeneous recyclable characteristics, which provided outstanding candidate for catalytic oxidation reactions of CH bond. coredata.dc:description: Converting C–H bonds into valuable compounds is a challenging goal in synthetic chemistry, yet it is both economically and environmentally beneficial. Developing high-efficiency catalysts for the oxidation of saturated C–H bonds is of great significance. Herein, a new cobalt-containing metal-organic complex, [Co2(L)0.5(MTC)(µ3-OH)(H2O)2]·2H2O (1, L = (E)-4,4′-(ethene-1,2-diyl)bis(N-(pyridin-3-yl)benzamide), H3MTC = benzene-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid), was successfully prepared with Co(NO3)2, ligand L and H3MTC through one-step hydrothermal synthesis. Complex 1 was found to be a highly effective heterogeneous catalyst for accelerating the oxidation reaction of alkylbenzenes to ketone products. The conversion of diphenylmethane to benzophenone over complex 1 was 95.6%, which was comparable to the highest values of reported transition metal-based catalysts. A possible catalytic reaction mechanism was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: A new metal−organic complex with coordination unsaturated Co(II) as high-efficiency heterogeneous catalyst for selective oxidation of alkylbenzenes
